item.description: It looks like my career path is taking a slight turn once again. Hopefully that means good things are ahead of me.

item.title: MacBook Pro 2013 Forever?
item.description:
Reviewing macOS 10.14 Mojave System Requirements makes me think I may only have one year of useful life left on my 2013 MacBook Pro. (Mid 2012 MacBook Pros are the oldest supported.)

If that‚Äôs true, it will be disappointing to me, because my laptop still feels fast and has plenty of computing resources. As a developer, I need to keep abreast of the current OS changes though, so I will have to upgrade when OS support is dropped.
I thought I understood the delegate pattern many years ago, but I keep finding more and more uses for it. If only it applied to real life.
The transformational Siri enhancements developers and pundits were hungry for were not announced at WWDC today. Apple is doomed! (OK, maybe not.)
If Microsoft wanted to scare everybody in the developer community, they would buy Stack Exchange too.

Microsoft bought GitHub just in time for WWDC to bury the news. I get the feeling that whatever led to GitHub‚Äôs success will soon be lost, but that it won‚Äôt matter to its profitability, and the vast majority of projects hosted there will stay. It just will never be the next GitHub.

I love this article about iOS app architecture:

Cocoa Touch is (I suspect) deliberately very simple: there‚Äôs Target-Action pattern, Dependency Injection, Delegate and MVC. That‚Äôs about it, really. Apparently it‚Äôs way too simple for some.

I am working on one or two practice projects right now, and can‚Äôt think of a better way to code them than MVC with Coordinators.

The drop shadows on all the WWDC promotional images and the new WWDC app icon are making me very nervous. I had to add drop shadows to everything back when I was in web development, back in 2000-2003. The effect looks so dated to me, but not so dated that it‚Äôs retro.
I am digging my old, blue, knockoff Apple Watch Sport Band again. I kind of wish I bought the real, fluoroelastomer band, though, because the silicone feels a little sticky and looks a little shiny.
It‚Äôs a muggy day in New Jersey, which is a great excuse to go to the beach. Plus there are rides on the boardwalk for the kids.
My wife and I are way back in the auditorium, waiting for ‚ÄúAn Evening with Stephen Sondheim‚Äù to begin.

SwiftoDo 2.13.0 is now available in the App Store. New features include a new hardware keyboard shortcut to paste into the task list, a long-press gesture on iPad to edit tasks in the task list, and some bug fixes.

I finally ‚Äúretired‚Äù my 9-year-old AeroPress today, in favor of a new one. The plunger end on the old one wore down to the point where it was causing problems. It will be nice to have a spare cap and coffee measuring scoop going forward.

It‚Äôs silly, but I am a little disappointed that AirPlay 2 will not be available on both Bang & Olufsen and B&O PLAY speakers until sometime during August or September 2018. I want multi room streaming with my BeoPlay M3 and my Apple TV now.
I‚Äôm finalizing another minor version update to SwiftoDo this week, despite the development freeze I had promised on my blog.
Here is a wrapper class to hide implementation details in Microsoft Access VBA projects: DAOQueryRunner.cls. DAOTemporaryTableController.cls relies on this.

This VBA class helps you work with temporary tables in Access VBA projects: DAOTemporaryTableController.cls. You may need to do so if you want to join using a subquery as criteria, which Access does not allow.
I decided to make use of GitHub Gists again. My first gist in several years is LoggedInUserName.bas: a VBA module to get logged in user name from the Windows API.
This New York Times article comfirms some of my suspicions that a lot of what we recycle does not actually get recycled. It amazes me that we ship recyclables around the world for processing.
üéô I am a sucker for an Upgrade draft episode: The WWDC keynote Draft 2018
All weekends should be 3 days long‚Ä¶if not 5! üòÄ
Yesterday was a lot of fun. My family enjoyed great weather, and oceanside fair to attend, lots of great food. Today is a total rainout, however. Hopefully we can find some good things to do indoors.

I unfollowed about 275 accounts on Twitter this afternoon. My Twitter feed had started to resemble a junk drawer to me. One thing I noticed is that 90% of the accounts I followed had not posted anything in months. (Let‚Äôs not even talk about how many bots are following me.)
I did not expect the Red Sox to designate Hanley Ramirez for assignment to make room for Dustin Pedroia.

SwiftoDo 2.12.0 is now available in the App Store. New features include a default option for new tasks, and an option to retain priority when completing tasks. There are tons of under-the-hood improvements, too.

item.title: It looks like Essential is going away
item.description:
Android Creator Puts Essential Up for Sale, Cancels Next Phone - Bloomberg

Current discussions are focused on a sale of the entire company, including its patent portfolio, hardware products like the original smartphone, an upcoming smart home device and a camera attachment for the phone, said the people, who asked not to be identified because the talks are private.

I got an Essential Phone in its release date, and was optimistic that the company would succeed. It looks like it hasn‚Äôt. Their first phone did have a bad camera experience (hardware and software-wise), which probably prevented any chance of success from the start. The Pixel and the Galaxy phones put it to shame. Plus, it must be next to impossible to make money selling Android phones. It‚Äôs not a business I would want to be in.

üì∫ I‚Äôm enjoying the ‚Äúremix‚Äù version of ‚ÄúArrested Development‚Äù season 4 a lot better than the original version. I‚Äôm sure time passing and my expectations being lowered helped, but I prefer to see all (most) of the characters in the same episodes.

I was so busy today that I forgot to blog! Hours of data analysis and database development will do that to me. It‚Äôs a beautiful sunny evening, and I‚Äôm heading off to a barbecue with my family now.
I‚Äôm pretty proud of my Ulysses library setup‚Äîat least the top level folder structure. My subfolders need a bit more organization, though.

item.title: üéµ First listen: Mean Girls (Original Broadway Cast)
item.description:
Mean Girls (Original Broadway Cast) is up for the Tony for best musical this year, and I think it has a legitimate shot. While this is a weak year for the American musical, the music of ‚ÄúMean Girls‚Äù is fun and catchy, and the lyrics are funny and full of wordplay. The singing and production of the cast album are top notch, too.

I like it. The high school setting and girl-centric plot, though not the music, remind me a lot of ‚ÄúBring It On‚Äù, which is another musical that has a fantastic cast album and works a lot better than you would think. I don‚Äôt know if this show will be a hit on Broadway, but I predict a long life on high school drama club stages in the future.
üéß Headphones review: Sony MDR-1AM2/B.

I used my iPad Pro and Pencil to teach my (kindergarten-age) daughter (üë©‚Äçüî¨) some bedtime math for the first time tonight. She loved writing the numbers in different colors in Apple Notes. I loved writing on something I could easily erase. It was really fun.
I just submitted SwiftoDo 2.12.0 to the App Store. Hopefully it‚Äôs good enough! üòÖ Expect a release toward the end of the week, if all goes well.
So much to do today, I don‚Äôt even know where to begin‚Ä¶
I took a new pair of headphones for a spin this evening. I think I may have a problem. üéßüòÇ
Blog post: ‚ÄúRecess‚Äù and ‚ÄúGood Bones‚Äù, or selling the world to my children

I‚Äôm still testing and fixing things in my dev build of SwiftoDo 2.12.0. It feels weird to have gone so long without issuing a release. I hope to get everything done next week. I have a very full weekend of family activities ahead of me, though, so I can‚Äôt do much till Monday.

item.title: üéµ Carry On
item.description:
On this bad and sad news day, remember:

If you‚Äôre lost and alone
Or you‚Äôre sinking like a stone
Carry on
May your past be the sound
Of your feed upon the ground and
Carry on

‚ÄòCause we are, we are shining stars
We are invincible
We are who we are
On our darkest day
When we‚Äôre miles away
So we‚Äôll come, we will find our way home

Fun.‚Äôs ‚ÄúCarry On‚Äù works well, and feels quite different, in this cover version by the cast of ‚ÄúRise‚Äù.

item.title: üéµ Frozen: The Broadway Musical
item.description: Listening to the cast recording of ‚ÄúFrozen: The Broadway Musical‚Äù for the first time is a bit surreal for me. Compared to the movie, there are new songs, lyrics changes in existing songs, and, of course, different singers. I don‚Äôt think any of the changes are for the better. It‚Äôs hard to say for sure, though, because, as a parent of a little girl, I‚Äôve heard the movie and the movie soundtrack about 1,000 times already, and it‚Äôs burned into my brain.

While I think I want a Nintendo Switch, I‚Äôm trying to make due for now with what I already have‚Äîan iPad Pro and a SteelSeries Nimbus controller. I‚Äôm not sure I even want to commit the time to gaming, but I am curious about the latest Mario and Zelda games.
Blog post: The calm before the WWDC storm
Google‚Äôs attractive but less information dense redesign of Google News may be the thing that finally breaks my addiction to it.

item.title: Google's music and video streaming strategy is a mess
item.description:
Engadget has it right. I have no idea what Google audio/video service I should ever consider subscribing to, and because music is tied in there, they don‚Äôt offer what I want (ad-free YouTube) at price that is reasonable to me. Maybe it doesn‚Äôt matter, because Google will just fold it and create an alternative service, with a different name, price, and product mix, in a couple years anyway.

As much as I rely on Google Search, and as much as I use, indifferently, Gmail, I just don‚Äôt understand Google as a company. Their central strategy appears to be ‚Äúno strategy‚Äù. They try stuff out, kill it if it fails, and iterate on what succeeds. This process is fun to watch when the company is a young startup, but is a bit much to bear when they are one of the four pillars of the internet.

If my kids didn‚Äôt love YouTube, but hate the ads, I wouldn‚Äôt think about subscribing to YouTube Premium (or is it YouTube Red? or is it YouTube Music?) at all. If Google cared about customers like me‚Äîvery light YouTube viewers who would pay a small amount of money to not be interrupted by ads‚ÄîI would send them some money each month.
My brain‚Äôs boot-up time is taking longer than usual today. ‚òïÔ∏è‚òïÔ∏è‚òïÔ∏è
The cast of Solo certainly is appealing, even if the movie itself may be largely inconsequential. To think, I used to care more about the director than the cast. üé¨
SwiftoDo 2.12.0 was looking pretty dire last night, but is now looking like it may be ready for release, thanks to some improvements I made today. I will do more testing this week to make sure.

Work has been heating up for me lately, which is good all around, but a change nonetheless. It‚Äôs good to have lots of work to look forward to each day. It‚Äôs bad to feel like there‚Äôs so much you can‚Äôt finish each day, too.
Am I late to the game with using semaphores, or are all the cool (cool?) kids using them these days?
I‚Äôm loving the second season of ‚ÄúWestworld‚Äù so far. I can‚Äôt wait to see how it all comes together in the end.

I have been testing what I thought would be SwiftoDo‚Äôs next release build all day. All day, Dropbox has been throwing error messages, making me think my code is messed up. Now, the same code is not throwing those error messages. It must be internet weather or something.
